name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA)
description: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) is a rare autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis) in the nose, sinuses, ears, lungs, and kidneys. It is often associated with the presence of anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) in the blood. GPA can cause a range of symptoms and, if left untreated, can lead to organ damage and even death.
ageOfOnset: Typically between 40 and 65 years, but can occur at any age
prognosis: With treatment, most people with GPA can achieve remission. However, relapses are common. Without treatment, GPA can be fatal.
lifeExpectancy: With treatment, life expectancy is near normal. Without treatment, life expectancy is significantly reduced.
keyResearchCenters: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)
eli5Summary: Imagine your body's defense system is attacking your blood vessels, especially in your nose, lungs, and kidneys. This causes swelling and damage, making it hard for those organs to work right. Doctors use strong medicines to calm down your defense system and stop it from attacking.
clinicalSummary: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) is a systemic autoimmune disease characterized by necrotizing granulomatous inflammation and vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels. The disease classically involves the upper and lower respiratory tracts and the kidneys, but can affect virtually any organ system. The pathogenesis involves ANCA-mediated neutrophil activation and endothelial damage. Diagnosis requires a combination of clinical findings, laboratory data (including ANCA testing), and histopathological evidence from biopsy. Treatment typically involves induction therapy with corticosteroids and immunosuppressants (e.g., cyclophosphamide or rituximab) followed by maintenance therapy to prevent relapse.
historicalBackground: GPA was first described by Friedrich Wegener in 1936. It was originally known as Wegener's Granulomatosis. Due to Wegener's association with Nazi activities, there has been a movement to rename the disease to Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA).

recentBreakthroughs.title: Rituximab Approved for GPA
recentBreakthroughs.description: Rituximab was approved by the FDA for the treatment of GPA, providing an alternative to cyclophosphamide.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Avacopan for ANCA-Associated Vasculitis
recentBreakthroughs.description: Avacopan, a selective C5a receptor inhibitor, has shown promise in clinical trials for the treatment of ANCA-associated vasculitis, including GPA, potentially reducing the need for high-dose corticosteroids.

sources.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)
